subsection.leadIn: In proceedings brought under this Ordinance against a person in respect of an act alleged to have been done by an intern engaged by the person, it is a defence for the person to prove that the person took reasonably practicable steps to prevent the intern—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from doing that act; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from doing acts of that description in the course of the internship.

subsection.content: Subsections (6) and (7) apply if a volunteer is engaged by another person to perform volunteer work.

subsection.leadIn: An act done by a volunteer in the course of performing volunteer work is to be treated as an act done—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the volunteer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the person who engaged the volunteer to perform the work, whether or not the act was done with the knowledge or approval of that person.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings brought under this Ordinance against a person in respect of an act alleged to have been done by a volunteer engaged by the person, it is a defence for the person to prove that the person took reasonably practicable steps to prevent the volunteer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from doing that act; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from doing acts of that description in the course of performing volunteer work.

subsection.content: A person who knowingly aids another person to do an act made unlawful by this Ordinance shall be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as himself doing an unlawful act of the like description.

For the purposes of subsection (1), an employee or agent for whose act the employer or principal is liable under section 46 (or would be so liable but for section 46(3)) shall be deemed to aid the doing of the act by the employer or principal.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), if a person who engaged an intern—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is liable under section 46A for an act done by the intern; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: would be liable under section 46A for the act but for section 46A(4),

subsection.continued: the intern is deemed to aid the doing of the act by that person. (Added 8 of 2020 s. 22)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), if a person who engaged a volunteer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is liable under section 46A for an act done by the volunteer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: would be liable under section 46A for the act but for section 46A(7),

subsection.continued: the volunteer is deemed to aid the doing of the act by that person. (Added 8 of 2020 s. 22)

subsection.leadIn: A person does not under this section knowingly aid another to do an unlawful act if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he acts in reliance on a statement made to him by that other person that, by reason of any provision of this Ordinance, the act which he aids would not be unlawful; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is reasonable for him to rely on the statement.

subsection.content: A person who knowingly or recklessly makes a statement of the kind referred to in subsection (3)(a) which in a material respect is false or misleading commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Special measures
section.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall render unlawful an act that is reasonably intended to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ensure that persons of a particular sex or marital status, or women who are pregnant or breastfeeding, have equal opportunities with other persons in circumstances in relation to which a provision is made by this Ordinance. (Amended 8 of 2020 s. 10)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: afford persons of a particular sex or marital status, or women who are pregnant or breastfeeding, goods or access to services, facilities or opportunities to meet their special needs in relation to— (Amended 8 of 2020 s. 10)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: employment, education, clubs or sport; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the provision of premises, goods, services or facilities;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: afford persons of a particular sex or marital status, or women who are pregnant or breastfeeding, grants, benefits or programmes, whether direct or indirect, to meet their special needs in relation to— (Amended 8 of 2020 s. 10)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: employment, education, clubs or sport; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the provision of premises, goods, services or facilities.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be construed as affecting a provision to which this subsection applies; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: render unlawful an act which is done in order to give effect to such a provision.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) applies to a provision for conferring benefits on persons of one sex only (disregarding any benefits to persons of the opposite sex which are exceptional or are relatively insignificant), being a provision which is contained in a charitable instrument.
In applying this section, account shall be taken of section 88 of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: charitable instrument (慈善文書) means an enactment or other instrument so far as it relates to charitable purposes;
charitable purposes (慈善目的) means purposes which are exclusively charitable according to any enactment or rule of law.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Sport, etc.
section.content: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall, in relation to any sport, game or other activity of a competitive nature where the physical strength, stamina or physique of the average woman puts her at a disadvantage to the average man, render unlawful any act related to the participation of a person as a competitor in events involving that activity which are confined to competitors of one sex.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Insurance, etc.
section.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall render unlawful the treatment of a person in relation to any class of insurance business, or similar matter involving the assessment of risk, where the treatment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was effected by reference to actuarial or other data from a source on which it was reasonable to rely; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was reasonable having regard to the data and any other relevant factors.

subsection.def: In this section communal accommodation (共用住宿地方) means residential accommodation which includes dormitories or other shared sleeping accommodation which for reasons of privacy or decency should be used by men only, or by women only (but which may include some shared sleeping accommodation for men, and some for women, or some ordinary sleeping accommodation).

In this section communal accommodation (共用住宿地方) also includes residential accommodation all or part of which should be used by men only, or by women only, because of the nature of the sanitary facilities serving the accommodation.

subsection.content: Nothing in Part 3 or 4 shall render unlawful sex discrimination in the admission of persons to communal accommodation if the accommodation is managed in a way which, given the exigencies of the situation, comes as near as may be to fair and equitable treatment of men and women.

subsection.leadIn: In applying subsection (3) account shall be taken of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether and how far it is reasonable to expect that the accommodation should be altered or extended, or that further alternative accommodation should be provided; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the frequency of the demand or need for use of the accommodation by men as compared with women.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3 or 4 shall render unlawful sex discrimination against a woman, or against a man, in respect of the provision of any benefit, facility or service if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the benefit, facility or service cannot properly and effectively be provided except for those using communal accommodation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the relevant circumstances the woman or the man, as the case may be, could lawfully be refused the use of the accommodation by virtue of subsection (3).

subsection.content: Neither subsection (3) nor subsection (5) is a defence to an act of sex discrimination under Part 3 unless such arrangements as are reasonably practicable are made to compensate for the detriment caused by the discrimination; but in considering under subsection (5)(b) whether the use of communal accommodation could lawfully be refused (in a case based on Part 3), it shall be assumed that the requirements of this subsection have been complied with in respect of subsection (3).
This section is without prejudice to the generality of section 34(1)(c).

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall render unlawful any act done in relation to particular work by any person in, or in connection with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affording women only, or men only, access to facilities for training which would help to fit them for that work; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: encouraging women only, or men only, to take advantage of opportunities for doing that work,

subsection.continued: where it reasonably appears to that person that at any time within the 12 months immediately preceding the doing of the act there were no persons of the sex concerned doing that work in Hong Kong, or the number of persons of that sex doing the work in Hong Kong was comparatively small.

subsection.content: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall render unlawful any act done by any person in, or in connection with, affording persons access to facilities for training which would help to fit them for employment, where it reasonably appears to that person that those persons are in special need of training by reason of the period for which they have been discharging domestic or family responsibilities to the exclusion of regular full time employment.

For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that the discrimination in relation to which subsection (2) applies may result from confining the training to persons who have been discharging domestic or family responsibilities, or from the way persons are selected for training, or both.
This section shall not apply in relation to any discrimination which is rendered unlawful by section 11.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall render unlawful any act done by an employer in relation to particular work in his employment, being an act done in, or in connection with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affording his female employees only, or his male employees only, access to facilities for training which would help to fit them for that work; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: encouraging women only, or men only, to take advantage of opportunities for doing that work,

subsection.continued: where at any time within the 12 months immediately preceding the doing of the act there were no persons of the sex concerned among those doing that work or the number of persons of that sex doing the work was comparatively small.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in section 16 shall render unlawful any act done by an organization to which that section applies in, or in connection with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affording female members of the organization only, or male members of the organization only, access to facilities for training which would help to fit them for holding a post of any kind in the organization; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: encouraging female members only, or male members only, to take advantage of opportunities for holding such posts in the organization,

subsection.continued: where at any time within the 12 months immediately preceding the doing of the act there were no persons of the sex concerned among persons holding such posts in the organization or the number of persons of that sex holding such posts was comparatively small.

subsection.content: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall render unlawful any act done by an organization to which section 16 applies in, or in connection with, encouraging women only, or men only, to become members of the organization where at any time within the 12 months immediately preceding the doing of the act there were no persons of the sex concerned among those members or the number of persons of that sex among the members was comparatively small.

subsection.leadIn: If an organization to which section 16 applies comprises a body the membership of which is wholly or mainly elected, nothing in that section shall render unlawful provision which ensures that a minimum number of persons of one sex are members of the body—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by reserving seats on the body for persons of that sex; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by making extra seats on the body available (by election or co-option or otherwise) for persons of that sex on occasions when the number of persons of that sex in the other seats is below the minimum,

subsection.continued: where in the opinion of the organization the provision is in the circumstances needed to secure a reasonable lower limit to the number of members of that sex serving on the body; and nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall render unlawful any act done in order to give effect to such a provision.

subsection.leadIn: This section shall not be taken as making lawful—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: discrimination in the arrangements for determining the persons entitled to vote in an election of members of the body, or otherwise to choose the persons to serve on the body; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: discrimination in any arrangements concerning membership of the organization itself.

subsection.content: References in this Ordinance to the affording by any person of access to benefits, facilities or services are not limited to benefits, facilities or services provided by that person himself, but include any means by which it is in that person’s power to facilitate access to benefits, facilities or services provided by any other person (actual provider).

Where by any provision of this Ordinance the affording by any person of access to benefits, facilities or services in a discriminatory way is in certain circumstances prevented from being unlawful, the effect of the provision shall extend also to the liability under this Ordinance of any actual provider.

For avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 renders it unlawful for a person to refuse or omit to provide a benefit or allowance relating to housing, education, air-conditioning, passage or baggage to a married person if the married person’s spouse receives or has received the same or a similar benefit or allowance, whether from the first-mentioned person or from another.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: allowance (津貼) includes part of an allowance;
benefit (福利) includes part of a benefit.

subsection.content: Nothing in Part 4 or 5 renders unlawful any discrimination between persons of different marital status arising from the provision of any reproductive technology procedure.

subsection.def: In this section, reproductive technology procedure (生殖科技程序) has the meaning assigned to it by section 2(1) of the Human Reproductive Technology Ordinance (Cap. 561). (Replaced 47 of 2000 s. 48)

section.name: s56C
section.heading: Adoption
section.content: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 renders unlawful any discrimination between persons of different marital status arising from the provision of any facilities or services relating to the adoption of any infant within the meaning of section 2 of the Adoption Ordinance (Cap. 290).

section.name: s57
section.heading: Acts done for purposes of protection of women

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the provisions of Part 3;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the provisions of Part 4 so far as it applies to vocational training; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the provisions of Part 5 so far as it has effect in relation to any of the provisions referred to in paragraph (a) or (b),

subsection.continued: shall render unlawful any act done by a person in relation to a woman if—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: it was necessary for that person to do it in order to comply with a requirement of an existing statutory provision concerning the protection of women. (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 17)

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the reference in paragraph (i) of that subsection to an existing statutory provision concerning the protection of women is a reference to any such provision having effect for the purpose of protecting women as regards—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: pregnancy or maternity; (Amended 8 of 2020 s. 11)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: breastfeeding; or (Added 8 of 2020 s. 11)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: other circumstances giving rise to risks specifically affecting women,

paragraph.continued: whether the provision relates only to such protection or to the protection of any other class of persons as well. (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 17)

section.name: s58
section.heading: Acts done under statutory authority to be exempt from certain provisions of Part 4

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the relevant provisions of Part 4; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Part 5 so far as it has effect in relation to those provisions,

subsection.continued: shall render unlawful any act done by a person if it was necessary for that person to do it in order to comply with a requirement of an existing statutory provision.

subsection.content: In subsection (1), the relevant provisions of Part 4 (第4部的有關條文) means the provisions of Part 4 except so far as they apply to vocational training or harassment. (Amended 3 of 2021 s. 12)

section.name: s59
section.heading: Acts safeguarding security of Hong Kong

subsection.content: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall render unlawful an act done for the purpose of safeguarding the security of Hong Kong.

A certificate purporting to be signed by or on behalf of the Chief Secretary for Administration and certifying that an act specified in the certificate was done for the purpose of safeguarding the security of Hong Kong shall be conclusive evidence that it was done for that purpose. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)
A document purporting to be a certificate referred to in subsection (2) shall be received in evidence and, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, shall be deemed to be such a certificate.

subsection.leadIn: Subsections (2) and (3) shall not have effect in relation to the determination of the question whether any act is rendered unlawful by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Part 3;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Part 4 so far as it applies to vocational training; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: Part 5 as read with—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: Part 3; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: Part 4 so far as it applies to vocational training.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Construction of references to vocational training
section.leadIn: In sections 57 and 58, vocational training (職業訓練) includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: retraining; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: vocational guidance.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: be construed as affecting the operation of any of the provisions of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the New Territories Ordinance (Cap. 97); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the New Territories Leases (Extension) Ordinance (Cap. 150); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: render unlawful any act done by any person in, or in connection with, the operation of any of those provisions.

subsection.content: No provision or Part of this Ordinance specified in column 1 of Part 2 of Schedule 5 shall render unlawful any discrimination specified opposite thereto in column 2 of that Part.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in Part 3, 4 or 5 shall render unlawful any act done by any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in connection with any discrimination which is not unlawful by virtue of the operation of subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the extent that it is done for the purposes of that discrimination.

subsection.content: There is hereby established a body corporate to be called the Equal Opportunities Commission.
The Commission shall have perpetual succession and a common seal and shall be capable of suing and being sued.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive shall appoint to be members of the Commission— (Amended 66 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Chairperson; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not less than 4 or more than 16 other members,

subsection.continued: each being an individual who is not a public officer.

subsection.content: The members of the Commission shall form its governing body with authority, in the name of the Commission, to perform the functions and exercise the powers of the Commission.

The members of the Commission may be appointed on a full-time or part-time basis as the Chief Executive thinks fit except that the Chairperson shall be appointed on a full-time basis. (Amended 66 of 1999 s. 3)
The relevant provisions of Schedule 6 shall have effect with respect to the Commission and its members.
The Commission shall not be regarded as a servant or agent of the Government or as enjoying any status, immunity or privilege of the Government.

Part VII of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) shall apply to the Commission and appointments to the Commission except in so far as that Part is inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance.
Every appointment under subsection (3) shall be notified in the Gazette.
The Chief Executive in Council may, by notice in the Gazette, amend subsection (3)(b) by substituting another number for any number appearing in that subsection. (Amended 66 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: The Commission shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: work towards the elimination of discrimination;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: promote equality of opportunity between men and women generally;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: work towards the elimination of harassment; (Amended 3 of 2021 s. 12)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of any act alleged to be unlawful by virtue of this Ordinance, encourage persons who are concerned with the matter to which the act relates to effect a settlement of the matter by conciliation, whether under section 84 or otherwise;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: keep under review the working of this Ordinance and, when it is so required by the Chief Executive or otherwise thinks it necessary, draw up and submit to the Chief Executive proposals for amending this Ordinance; and (Amended 66 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: perform such other functions as are imposed on it under this Ordinance or any other enactment.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may do all such things as are necessary for, or incidental or conducive to, the better performance of its functions and in particular but without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing, may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: establish such committees as it thinks fit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: acquire and hold property of any description if in the opinion of the Commission such property is necessary for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the accommodation of the Commission or of any committee; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the performance of any function which the Commission may perform,

paragraph.continued: and, subject to the terms and conditions upon which such property is held, dispose of it;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: enter into, carry out, assign or accept the assignment of, vary or rescind, any contract, agreement or other obligation;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: employ such persons as it thinks fit to carry out any matter relating to the performance of its functions or the exercise of its powers;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (d), engage the services of such persons as it thinks fit to carry out any matter relating to the performance of its functions or the exercise of its powers under section 84;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: engage the services of such technical and professional advisers as it thinks fit to advise the Commission on any matter relating to the performance of its functions or the exercise of its powers;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: undertake and execute any lawful trust which has as an object the furtherance of any function which the Commission is required or is permitted by this Ordinance to perform or any other similar object;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: accept and solicit gifts and donations, whether subject to any trust or not;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: with the prior approval of the Chief Executive, become a member of or affiliate to any international body concerned with (whether in whole or in part) the elimination of discrimination; (Amended 66 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: exercise such other powers as are conferred on it under this Ordinance or any other enactment.

subsection.content: The relevant provisions of Schedule 6 shall have effect with respect to a committee and its members.

Part VII of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) shall apply to a committee and appointments to the committee except in so far as that Part is inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance.

The Commission may undertake or assist (financially or otherwise) the undertaking by other persons of any research, and any educational activities, which appear to the Commission necessary or expedient for the performance of its functions.
The Commission may impose reasonable charges for educational or other facilities or services made available by it.

The Commission shall not provide any financial assistance under subsection (1) except with the prior approval of the Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs given, after consulting with the Secretary for Financial Services and the Treasury, generally or in any particular case. (Amended L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007)

Without prejudice to the generality of section 64(1), the Commission, pursuant to its functions under paragraphs (a) and (b) of that section, shall keep Schedule 5 under review. (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 18)

subsection.leadIn: Whenever the Commission thinks it necessary, it shall draw up and submit to the Chief Executive proposals for— (Amended 66 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: amending Schedule 5.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), the Commission may, with or without restrictions as it thinks fit, delegate in writing any of its functions or powers to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any member of the Commission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any committee;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any employee of the Commission;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any conciliator.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission shall not delegate any of its functions or powers under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subsection (1) or section 64(2)(a) or 88;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any provisions of any regulations made under section 89 which are specified in the regulations as provisions which shall not be subject to subsection (1);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any provisions of any rules made under section 88 which are specified in the rules as provisions which shall not be subject to subsection (1);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any provisions of Schedule 6 which are specified in that Schedule as provisions which shall not be subject to subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: A delegate of the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall perform the delegated functions and may exercise the delegated powers as if the delegate were the Commission; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall be presumed to be acting in accordance with the relevant delegation in the absence of evidence to the contrary.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Protection of members of Commission, etc.

subsection.content: No person to whom this subsection applies, acting in good faith, is personally liable in damages for any act done or default made in the performance or purported performance of any function, or the exercise or purported exercise of any power, imposed or conferred on the Commission under this Ordinance.

The protection conferred by subsection (1) on any person to whom that subsection applies in respect of any act or default does not in any way affect the liability of the Commission for that act or default.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) applies to the following persons— (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 19)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a member of the Commission or a committee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an employee of the Commission;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a conciliator.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may issue codes of practice containing such practical guidance as it thinks fit for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the elimination of discrimination;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the promotion of equality of opportunity between men and women generally;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the elimination of harassment. (Amended 3 of 2021 s. 12)

subsection.content: When the Commission proposes to issue a code of practice, it shall prepare and publish (otherwise than in the Gazette) the code, shall consider any representations made to it about the code and may modify the code accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: In the course of preparing any code of practice for eventual publication under subsection (2), the Commission shall, where the code relates (whether in whole or in part) to the elimination of discrimination in the field of employment, consult with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such organizations or associations of organizations representative of employers or of workers; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such other organizations, or bodies,

subsection.continued: as appear to the Commission to be appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission determines to proceed with a code of practice published under subsection (2), it shall cause the code to be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: published in the Gazette; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: laid on the table of the Legislative Council at the next sitting after its publication in the Gazette.

subsection.content: Where a code of practice has been laid on the table of the Legislative Council under subsection (4), the Legislative Council may, by resolution passed at a sitting of the Legislative Council held before the expiration of a period of 28 days after the sitting at which it was so laid, provide that the code of practice shall be amended in any manner consistent with this section.

subsection.leadIn: If the period referred to in subsection (5) would but for this subsection expire—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after the end of a session of the Legislative Council or a dissolution thereof; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on or before the day of the second sitting of the Legislative Council in the next following session thereof,

subsection.continued: that period shall be deemed to extend to and expire on the day after that second sitting.

subsection.leadIn: Before the expiration of the period referred to in subsection (5) or that period as extended by virtue of subsection (6), the Legislative Council may by resolution in relation to a code of practice specified therein—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in the case where the period referred to in subsection (5) has been extended by virtue of subsection (6), extend that period as so extended to the first sitting of the Legislative Council held not earlier than the twenty-first day after the day of the second sitting in that next following session. (Replaced 8 of 2002 s. 18)

subsection.content: A resolution passed by the Legislative Council in accordance with this section shall be published in the Gazette not later than 14 days after the passing thereof or within such further period as the Chief Executive may allow in any particular case. (Amended 66 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: A code of practice issued under this section shall come into operation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case where before the expiration of the period referred to in subsection (5), or before the expiration of that period as extended under subsection (6) or (7), the Legislative Council does not pass a resolution amending the code of practice, upon the expiration of that period, or upon the expiration of that period as so extended, as the case may be; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case where the Legislative Council passes a resolution amending the code of practice, upon the expiration of the day next preceding the day of the publication in the Gazette of such resolution under subsection (8).

subsection.content: A code of practice issued under this section may contain such transitional provisions or savings as appear to the Commission to be necessary or expedient in connection with the matters the subject of the code.

The Commission may from time to time revise the whole or any part of a code of practice issued under this section and issue that revised code, and subsections (2) to (10) shall apply (with appropriate modifications) to such a revised code as they apply to the first issue of a code.

Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (1), a code of practice issued under this section may include such practical guidance as the Commission thinks fit as to what steps it is reasonably practicable for employers to take for the purpose of preventing their employees from doing in the course of their employment acts made unlawful by this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (1), a code of practice issued under this section, in so far as it relates to the elimination of discrimination between men and women as regards terms of employment, may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: incorporate any of those provisions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: both make reference to and incorporate any of those provisions,

subsection.continued: as the Commission thinks fit and subject to such modifications, if any, to those provisions as the Commission thinks fit and specified in the code.

subsection.content: A failure on the part of any person to observe any provision of a code of practice shall not of itself render him liable to any proceedings; but in any proceedings under this Ordinance before any court any code of practice issued under this section shall be admissible in evidence, and if any provision of such a code appears to the court to be relevant to any question arising in the proceedings it shall be taken into account in determining that question.

subsection.def: In this section, sitting (會議), when used to calculate time, means the day on which the sitting commences and only includes a sitting at which subsidiary legislation is included on the order paper.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Power to conduct formal investigations
section.content: Without prejudice to the generality of section 64(1), the Commission may if it thinks fit, and shall if required by the Chief Secretary for Administration, conduct a formal investigation for any purpose connected with the carrying out of any of its functions under that section.

subsection.content: The Commission shall not embark on a formal investigation unless the requirements of this section have been complied with.

Terms of reference for the formal investigation shall be drawn up by the Commission or, if the Commission was required by the Chief Secretary for Administration to conduct the investigation, by the Chief Secretary for Administration after consulting the Commission. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

It shall be the duty of the Commission to give general notice of the holding of the formal investigation unless the terms of reference confine it to activities of persons named in them, but in such a case the Commission shall in the prescribed manner give those persons notice of the holding of the investigation.

subsection.leadIn: Where the terms of reference of the formal investigation confine it to activities of persons named in them and the Commission in the course of it proposes to investigate any act made unlawful by this Ordinance which it believes that a person so named may have done, the Commission shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inform that person of its belief and of its proposal to investigate the act; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: offer him an opportunity of making oral or written representations with regard to it (or both oral and written representations if he thinks fit),

subsection.continued: and a person so named who avails himself of an opportunity under this subsection of making oral representations may be represented—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: by counsel or a solicitor; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: by some other person of his choice, not being a person to whom the Commission objects on the ground that he is unsuitable.

subsection.content: The Commission or, if the Commission was required by the Chief Secretary for Administration to conduct the formal investigation, the Chief Secretary for Administration after consulting the Commission may from time to time revise the terms of reference; and subsections (1), (3) and (4) shall apply to the revised investigation and terms of reference as they applied to the original. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of a formal investigation the Commission, by a notice in the prescribed form served on him in the prescribed manner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may require any person to furnish such written information as may be described in the notice, and may specify the time at which, and the manner and form in which, the information is to be furnished;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may require any person to attend at such time and place as is specified in the notice and give oral information about, and produce all documents in his possession or control relating to, any matter specified in the notice.

subsection.leadIn: Except as provided by section 79, a notice shall be served under subsection (1) only where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: service of the notice was authorized in writing by or on behalf of the Chief Secretary for Administration; or (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the terms of reference of the formal investigation state that the Commission believes that a person named in them may have done or may be doing acts of all or any of the following descriptions—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: unlawful discriminatory acts;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: unlawful acts of harassment; (Amended 3 of 2021 s. 12)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: contraventions of section 42;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: contraventions of section 43, 44 or 45,

paragraph.continued: and confine the investigation to those acts.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (1) shall not require a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to give information, or produce any documents, which he could not be compelled to give in evidence, or produce, in civil proceedings before the Court of First Instance; or (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to attend at any place unless the necessary expenses of his journey to and from that place are paid or tendered to him.

subsection.content: If a person fails to comply with a notice served on him under subsection (1) or the Commission has reasonable cause to believe that he intends not to comply with it, the Commission may apply to the District Court for an order requiring him to comply with it or with such directions for the like purpose as may be contained in the order; and section 66A of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) shall apply to failure without reasonable excuse to comply with any such order as it applies in the cases there provided.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: wilfully alters, suppresses, conceals or destroys a document which he has been required by a notice or order under this section to produce; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in complying with such a notice or order, knowingly or recklessly makes any statement which in a material respect is false or misleading,

subsection.continued: and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Recommendations and reports on formal investigations

subsection.leadIn: If in the light of any of its findings in a formal investigation it appears to the Commission necessary or expedient, whether during the course of the investigation or after its conclusion—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to make to any persons, with a view to promoting equality of opportunity between men and women who are affected by any of their activities, recommendations for changes in their policies or procedures, or as to any other matters; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to make to the Chief Secretary for Administration any recommendations, whether for changes in the law or otherwise, (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.continued: the Commission shall make those recommendations accordingly.

subsection.content: The Commission shall prepare a report of its findings in any formal investigation conducted by it.

subsection.leadIn: If the formal investigation is one required by the Chief Secretary for Administration—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commission shall deliver the report to the Chief Secretary for Administration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Chief Secretary for Administration shall cause the report to be published in such manner as he thinks fit,

subsection.continued: and unless required by the Chief Secretary for Administration the Commission shall not publish the report. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.content: If the formal investigation is not one required by the Chief Secretary for Administration, the Commission shall publish the report or make it available for inspection in accordance with subsection (5). (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: Where under subsection (4) a report is to be made available for inspection, any person shall be entitled, on payment of such reasonable fee, if any, as may be determined by the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to inspect the report during ordinary office hours and take copies of all or any part of the report; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to obtain from the Commission a copy, certified by the Commission to be correct, of the report.

subsection.content: The Commission may if it thinks fit determine that the right conferred by subsection (5)(a) shall be exercisable in relation to a copy of the report instead of, or in addition to, the original.
The Commission shall give general notice of the place or places where, and the times when, reports may be inspected under subsection (5).

subsection.leadIn: No information given to the Commission by any person (the informant) in connection with a formal investigation shall be disclosed by the Commission, any member of the Commission or a committee, any employee of the Commission, any conciliator, or any person who has been such a member, employee or conciliator, except—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the order of any court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: with the informant’s consent;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the form of a summary or other general statement published by the Commission which does not identify the informant or any other person to whom the information relates;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in a report of the investigation published by the Commission or made available for inspection under section 73(5);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to members of the Commission or a committee, employees of the Commission or conciliators or, so far as may be necessary for the proper performance of the functions of the Commission, to other persons;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: for the purpose of any civil proceedings under this Ordinance to which the Commission is a party, or any criminal proceedings.

subsection.content: Any person who discloses information in contravention of subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

In preparing any report for publication or for inspection the Commission shall exclude, so far as is consistent with its functions and the object of the report, any matter which relates to the private affairs of any individual or business interests of any person where the publication of that matter might, in the opinion of the Commission, prejudicially affect that individual or person.

part.name: P8
part.heading: Enforcement

section.name: s75
section.heading: Restrictions of proceedings for contravention of Ordinance

subsection.content: Except as provided by this Ordinance no proceedings, whether civil or criminal, shall lie against any person in respect of an act by reason that the act is unlawful by virtue of a provision of this Ordinance.
Subsection (1) shall not preclude the making of an order of certiorari, mandamus or prohibition.

subsection.leadIn: A claim by any person (the claimant) that another person (the respondent)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has committed an act of discrimination against the claimant which is unlawful by virtue of Part 3 or 4;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has committed an act of harassment against the claimant which is unlawful by virtue of Part 3 or 4; or (Amended 29 of 2008 s. 95; 3 of 2021 s. 12)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: is to be treated, by virtue of section 46, 46A or 47, as having committed an act of discrimination or harassment referred to in paragraph (a) or (c) against the claimant, (Added 29 of 2008 s. 95. Amended 8 of 2020 s. 23; 3 of 2021 s. 12)

subsection.continued: may be made the subject of civil proceedings in like manner as any other claim in tort.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) shall not apply to a claim under section 17(1) of an act in respect of which an appeal, or proceedings in the nature of an appeal, may be brought under any enactment.

Proceedings under subsection (1) shall be brought in the District Court but all such remedies shall be obtainable in such proceedings as, apart from this subsection and section 75(1), would be obtainable in the Court of First Instance. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of the power conferred by subsection (3), the District Court may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall perform any reasonable act or course of conduct to redress any loss or damage suffered by the claimant;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall employ or re-employ the claimant;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall promote the claimant;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall pay to the claimant punitive or exemplary damages; or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: make an order declaring void in whole or part and either ab initio or from such date as may be specified in the order, any contract or agreement made in contravention of this Ordinance. (Added 71 of 1997 s. 7)

subsection.content: By virtue of this subsection and notwithstanding any law, the District Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine any proceedings under subsection (1) and shall have all such powers as are necessary or expedient for it to have in order to provide, grant or make any remedy, injunction or order mentioned in this Ordinance. (Replaced 71 of 1997 s. 6)

In respect of an unlawful act of discrimination falling within section 5(1)(b), 7(1)(b) or 8(b), no award of damages shall be made if the respondent proves that the requirement or condition concerned was not applied with the intention of treating the claimant unfavourably on the ground of the claimant’s sex, marital status or pregnancy, as the case may be.

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.content: Subsection (5) does not apply in relation to an unlawful act of discrimination falling within section 5(1)(b), 7(1)(b) or 8(b) that is committed on or after the commencement date* of Part 9 of the Discrimination Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Ordinance 2020 (8 of 2020). (Added 8 of 2020 s. 42)

For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that damages in respect of an unlawful act of discrimination or harassment may include compensation for injury to feelings whether or not they include compensation under any other head. (Amended 3 of 2021 s. 12)

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to any act which is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an unlawful discriminatory act;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an unlawful act of harassment; (Amended 3 of 2021 s. 12)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a contravention of section 42; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a contravention of section 43, 44 or 45,

subsection.continued: and so applies whether or not proceedings have been brought in respect of the act.

subsection.leadIn: If in the course of a formal investigation the Commission becomes satisfied that a person is committing, or has committed, any acts to which this section applies, the Commission may in the prescribed manner serve on him a notice in the prescribed form requiring him—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not to commit any such acts (which may include discontinuing or changing any of his practices or other arrangements which occasioned those acts, in particular to avoid any repetition thereof); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where compliance with paragraph (a) involves changes in any of his practices or other arrangements—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to inform the Commission that he has effected those changes and what those changes are; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to take such steps as may be reasonably required by the notice for the purpose of affording that information to other persons concerned.

subsection.content: An enforcement notice may also require the person on whom it is served to furnish the Commission with such other information as may be reasonably required by the notice in order to verify that the notice has been complied with.

An enforcement notice may specify the time at which, and the manner and form in which, any information is to be furnished to the Commission, but the time at which any information is to be furnished in compliance with the notice shall not be later than 5 years after the notice has become final.

Section 72(4) shall apply to requirements under subsections (2)(b), (3) and (4) contained in an enforcement notice which has become final as it applies to requirements in a notice served under section 72(1).
Not later than 45 days after an enforcment notice is served on any person he may appeal against any requirement of the notice to the District Court.

Where the District Court considers a requirement in respect of which an appeal is brought under subsection (1) to be unreasonable because it is based on an incorrect finding of fact or for any other reason, the Court shall quash the requirement.

On quashing a requirement under subsection (2), the District Court may direct that the enforcement notice shall be treated as if, in place of the requirement quashed, it had contained a requirement in terms specified in the direction.
Subsection (1) shall not apply to a requirement treated as included in an enforcement notice by virtue of a direction under subsection (3).

section.name: s79
section.heading: Investigation as to compliance with enforcement notice

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the terms of reference of a formal investigation state that its purpose is to determine whether any requirements of an enforcement notice are being or have been carried out, but section 72(2)(b) does not apply; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.def: section 71(3) is complied with in relation to the investigation on a date (the commencement date) not later than the expiration of the period of 5 years beginning when the enforcement notice became final,

subsection.continued: the Commission may within the relevant period serve notices under section 72(1) for the purposes of the investigation without needing to obtain the consent of the Chief Secretary for Administration. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

def.name: RelevantPeriod
def.leadIn: In subsection (1), relevant period (有關期間) means the period beginning on the commencement date and ending on the later of the following dates—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the period of 5 years referred to in subsection (1)(b) expires;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date 2 years after the commencement date.

subsection.def: The Commission shall establish and maintain a register (the register) of enforcement notices which have become final.

subsection.leadIn: Any person shall be entitled, on payment of such reasonable fee, if any, as may be determined by the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to inspect the register during ordinary office hours and take copies of any entry; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to obtain from the Commission a copy, certified by the Commission to be correct, of any entry in the register.

subsection.content: The Commission may, if it thinks fit, determine that the right conferred by subsection (2)(a) shall be exercisable in relation to a copy of the register instead of, or in addition to, the original.
The Commission shall give general notice of the place or places where, and the times when, the register or a copy of it may be inspected.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Persistent discrimination or harassment
section.leadIn: If, during the period of 5 years beginning on the date on which either of the following became final in the case of any person, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an enforcement notice served on him;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a finding by the District Court under section 76 that he has done an unlawful discriminatory act or unlawful act of harassment, (Amended 3 of 2021 s. 11)

section.continued: it appears to the Commission that unless restrained he is likely to do one or more acts falling within paragraph (b), or contravening section 42, the Commission may apply to the District Court for an injunction restraining him from doing so; and the District Court, if satisfied that the application is well-founded, may grant the injunction in the terms applied for or in more limited terms.

subsection.content: Proceedings in respect of a contravention of section 43, 44 or 45 shall be brought only by the Commission in accordance with the provisions of this section.

subsection.leadIn: The proceedings shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application for a decision whether the alleged contravention occurred; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application under subsection (4),

subsection.continued: or both.

subsection.content: An application under subsection (2)(a) shall be made to the District Court.

subsection.leadIn: If it appears to the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a person has done an act which by virtue of section 43, 44 or 45 was unlawful; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that unless restrained he is likely to do further acts which by virtue of that section are unlawful,

subsection.continued: the Commission may apply to the District Court for an injunction restraining him from doing so; and the District Court, if satisfied that the application is well-founded, may grant the injunction in the terms applied for or in more limited terms.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to subsection (4), if it appears to the Commission that a person has done an act which was unlawful by virtue of section 43, the Commission may apply to the District Court for an order imposing a financial penalty on such person; and the District Court, if satisfied that the application is well-founded, may make such an order.

The financial penalty imposed under subsection (5) shall not exceed $10,000 for the first occasion on which a penalty is imposed, and $30,000 for the second and any subsequent occasion on which a penalty is imposed in respect of the same person.

part.crossHeading: Help for Persons Suffering Discrimination or Harassment

section.name: s83
section.heading: Help for aggrieved persons in obtaining information, etc.

def.name: ThePersonAggrieved
def.leadIn: With a view to helping a person (the person aggrieved) who considers he may have been discriminated against or harassed in contravention of this Ordinance to decide whether to institute proceedings and, if he does so, to formulate and present his case in the most effective manner, the Commission may prescribe— (Amended 3 of 2021 s. 13)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: forms by which the respondent may if he so wishes reply to any questions.

subsection.leadIn: Where the person aggrieved questions the respondent (whether or not in accordance with forms referred to in subsection (1))—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: if it appears to the District Court that the respondent deliberately, and without reasonable excuse, omitted to reply within a reasonable period or that his reply is evasive or equivocal, the Court may draw any inference from that fact it considers it just and equitable to draw, including an inference that he committed an unlawful act.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribe the period within which questions must be served in order to be admissible under subsection (2)(a);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribe the manner in which a question, and any reply by the respondent, may be served.

subsection.content: Rules under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) may enable the District Court entertaining a claim under section 76 to determine, before the date fixed for the hearing of the claim, whether a question or reply is admissible under this section or not.

This section is without prejudice to any other enactment or rule of law regulating interlocutory and preliminary matters in proceedings before the District Court, and has effect subject to any enactment or rule of law regulating the admissibility of evidence in such proceedings.

subsection.def: In this section, respondent (答辯人) includes a prospective respondent.

subsection.content: A person may lodge with the Commission a complaint in writing alleging that another person has done an act which is unlawful by virtue of a provision of this Ordinance.
A representative complaint may be lodged under subsection (1) in accordance with rules made under section 88.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), where a complaint is lodged under subsection (1), the Commission shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: conduct an investigation into the act the subject of the complaint; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: endeavour, by conciliation, to effect a settlement of the matter to which the act relates.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may decide not to conduct, or to discontinue, an investigation into an act the subject of a complaint lodged under subsection (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is satisfied that the act is not unlawful by reason of a provision of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is of the opinion that the person aggrieved by the act does not desire (or, in a case to which subsection (2) applies, none of the persons aggrieved by the act desires) that the investigation be conducted or continued;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a period of more than 12 months has elapsed beginning when the act was done;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in a case to which subsection (2) applies, it determines, in accordance with rules made under section 88, that the complaint should not be a representative complaint; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: it is of the opinion that the complaint is frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commission decides not to conduct, or to discontinue, an investigation into an act the subject of a complaint lodged under subsection (1), it shall by notice served on the person who lodged the complaint advise him of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reasons for that decision.

subsection.content: Evidence of anything said or done by any person in the course of conciliation under this section (including anything said or done at any conference held for the purposes of such conciliation) is not admissible in evidence in any proceedings under this Ordinance except with the consent of that person.

subsection.leadIn: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that subsection (6) shall not apply where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a complaint is lodged under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a settlement has been effected of the matter to which the act the subject of the complaint relates.

section.name: s85
section.heading: Assistance other than by way of conciliation

subsection.content: Where a complaint has been lodged under section 84(1) but, for whatever reason, there has not been a settlement of the matter to which the act the subject of the complaint relates, then any person who may institute proceedings under this Ordinance in respect of that act may make an application to the Commission for assistance in respect of those proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission shall consider an application under subsection (1) and may grant it if it thinks fit to do so, in particular where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the case raises a question of principle; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is unreasonable, having regard to the complexity of the case or the applicant’s position in relation to the respondent or another person involved or any other matter, to expect the applicant to deal with the case unaided.

subsection.leadIn: Assistance by the Commission under this section may include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: giving advice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: arranging for the giving of advice or assistance by a solicitor or counsel;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: arranging for representation by any person including all such assistance as is usually given by a solicitor or counsel in the steps preliminary or incidental to any proceedings, or in arriving at or giving effect to a compromise to avoid or bring to an end any proceedings;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other form of assistance which the Commission may consider appropriate,

subsection.continued: but paragraph (c) shall not affect the law and practice regulating the descriptions of persons who may appear in, conduct, defend and address a court in, any proceedings except to the extent permitted under rules made in accordance with section 73B of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336).

subsection.leadIn: In so far as expenses are incurred by the Commission in providing the applicant with assistance under this section the recovery of those expenses (as taxed or assessed in such manner as may be prescribed by relevant rules) shall constitute a first charge for the benefit of the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on any costs or expenses which (whether by virtue of a judgment or order of the District Court or an agreement or otherwise) are payable to the applicant by any other person in respect of the matter in connection with which the assistance is given; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so far as relates to any costs or expenses, on his rights under any compromise or settlement arrived at in connection with that matter to avoid or bring to an end any proceedings.

subsection.content: The charge conferred by subsection (4) shall be subject to any charge under the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91) and to any provision in that Ordinance for payment of any sum into the Supplementary Legal Aid Fund established under that Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant rules (有關規則) means any rules made under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336);
respondent (答辯人) includes a prospective respondent.

part.crossHeading: Period within which Proceedings to be Brought

section.name: s86
section.heading: Period within which proceedings to be brought

subsection.leadIn: The District Court shall not consider a claim under section 76 unless proceedings in respect of the claim are instituted before the end of the period of 24 months beginning—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when the act complained of was done; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if there is a relevant report in relation to that act, with the day on which the report is published or made available for inspection under section 73,

subsection.continued: whichever is the later.

subsection.leadIn: The District Court shall not consider an application under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 82(2)(a) unless it is made before the end of the period of 24 months beginning when the act to which it relates was done;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 82(4) unless it is made before the end of the period of 5 years so beginning.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: For the purposes of determining the period under subsection (1) within which proceedings may be brought, where an act to which the claim relates was the subject of a complaint lodged under section 84(1), then the period that elapsed between the date when the complaint was lodged and the date when the complaint was disposed of under section 84(3) or (4), as certified in writing by the Commission, shall be disregarded. (Added 71 of 1997 s. 8. Amended 29 of 2008 s. 96)

Notwithstanding subsections (1) and (2), the District Court may consider any claim or application which is out of time if, in all the circumstances of the case, it considers that it is just and equitable to do so.

For the purposes of subsection (3), the circumstances of the case include, in relation to any claim, whether the act to which the claim relates was the subject of a complaint lodged under section 84(1) and, if so, the period that elapsed between when the act was done and when that complaint was so lodged.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: any act extending over a period shall be treated as done at the end of that period; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a deliberate omission shall be treated as done when the person concerned decided upon it,

subsection.continued: and, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, a person shall be taken for the purposes of this section to decide upon an omission when he does an act inconsistent with doing the omitted act or, if he has done no such inconsistent act, when the period expires within which he might reasonably have been expected to do the omitted act if it was to be done.

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may, by notice in the Gazette, amend subsection (1) by substituting a longer period for the period specified in that subsection. (Amended 66 of 1999 s. 3)

def.name: RelevantReport
def.leadIn: In this section, relevant report (有關報告), in relation to an act referred to in subsection (1), means a report—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: from which it can reasonably be construed (and whether or not the report mentions, or was in any way prepared in consequence of, the act) that the Commission is of the opinion that the act, or the class of acts to which the act belongs, is unlawful under a provision of Part 3, 4 or 5.

subsection.leadIn: A term of a contract is void where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its inclusion renders the making of the contract unlawful by virtue of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is included in furtherance of an act rendered unlawful by this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it provides for the doing of an act which would be rendered unlawful by this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) shall not apply to a term the inclusion of which constitutes, or is in furtherance of, or provides for, unlawful discrimination against a party to the contract, but the term shall be unenforceable against that party.
A term in a contract which purports to exclude or limit any provision of this Ordinance is unenforceable by any person in whose favour the term would operate apart from this subsection.
Subsection (3) shall not apply to a contract settling a claim to which section 76 applies.

On the application of any person interested in a contract to which subsection (2) applies, the District Court may make such order as it thinks just for removing or modifying any term made unenforceable by that subsection; but such an order shall not be made unless all persons affected have been given notice of the application (except where under rules made under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) notice may be dispensed with) and have been afforded an opportunity to make representations to the Court.
An order under subsection (5) may include provision as respects any period before the making of the order.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribing the persons, or persons belonging to a class of persons, who may lodge a representative complaint under section 84(1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribing the bodies and positions for the purposes of section 35;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: prescribing the matters to be taken into account by the Commission for the purposes of a determination under section 84(4)(d);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to enable the Commission to require such persons, or persons belonging to such class of persons, as are specified in the rules to furnish information to the Commission for the purposes of section 84;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: restricting the disclosure of any information referred to in paragraph (d) furnished to the Commission;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to enable the Commission to direct persons to attend any conference held for the purposes of section 84;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: regulating the procedure of any conference held for the purposes of section 84;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: prescribing any other thing that is required or permitted to be prescribed under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Any rules made under subsection (1) may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make different provisions for different circumstances and provide for a particular case or class of cases;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be made so as to apply only in such circumstances as are prescribed by the rules;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify forms for the purposes of the rules;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: be made generally for the better or more effectual carrying out of the provisions of this Ordinance, including incidental, consequential, evidential and supplemental provisions.

subsection.content: Any rules made under this section may prescribe offences in respect of contraventions of the rules, and may provide for the imposition of a fine not exceeding level 4 and of imprisonment for a period not exceeding 2 years.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Regulations to empower Commission to bring certain proceedings

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs may make regulations— (Amended L.N. 130 of 2007)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where any person may bring proceedings under section 76(1) but has not done so, empowering the Commission, in such circumstances as are specified in the regulations, to bring and maintain those proceedings as if the Commission were that person;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: for the purposes of enabling the Commission to bring and maintain any such proceedings (including any related purposes), specifying modifications to which any provisions of this Ordinance (including any subsidiary legislation) shall be read.

subsection.content: Any regulations made under this section shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.

This section is without prejudice to the Commission’s power to bring proceedings by way of judicial review, in relation to this Ordinance or any other law, pursuant to its functions under section 64(1). (Added 71 of 1997 s. 9)

The Chief Executive in Council may, by notice in the Gazette, amend Schedule 1, 4 or 5 but any notice to amend Schedule 5 shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council. (Amended 71 of 1997 s. 10; 66 of 1999 s. 3; 18 of 2014 s. 20)
The Legislative Council may, by resolution, amend Schedule 6.
The provisions of Schedule 7 shall have effect as transitional provisions for the purposes of this Ordinance.
